post_text:
Chelsea Henderson on Earle High School Computer Science Students:

"It was incredible to see my students become the teacher in this engaging lesson. I worked with the Elementary school teacher, David Knight to pair each 6th grade math student up with a senior in AP Computer Science Principles at the high school. The seniors had been given lessons the prior week using the Chibi Chip and the goal was they were to get their Elementary school buddy to understand circuits, simple code, and be able to communicate their knowledge. It was so great to be able to watch my students struggle with the notion that when teaching it to younger students they couldn’t just do it for them and that they had to ask them probing questions to figure out a solution on their own. This lesson went incredibly smooth and we will be sure to look for other ways that the CS class can pair with the elementary school and community going forward!"

Thank you to EHS students for engaging EES students in coding! #makeadifference

The Arkansas State Police has been in close contact in recent days with the Federal Bureau of Investigation attemping to identify the source of an alleged threat of gun violence at an undisclosed Arkansas school reportedly planned for later this week.

At this time no corroborating evidence or useful details have been uncovered in regard to the information provided to the FBI.

In the event more specific or credible information is received; it will be shared with local law enforcement offices, state and local school officials, as well as Arkansas citizens.

The Arkansas State Police asks that if anyone has information about a threat of violence whether the site of the threat may be a school or other public place, please contact your nearest Arkansas State Police Office or local law enforcement agency.

We have received no direct threats to Earle School District, and will continue to work with our SROs, city, and county officials to keep our students and staff safe.

Tish Knowles
Superintendent

Today’s Amazing Arkansas Teacher, Sontreka Johnson, has been teaching seven years and is currently the Algebra I teacher at Jacksonville High School. She lets her students know the first day, “Math was hard before you met me!” Sontreka builds relationships before she opens her lesson plan book. “I want my scholars to know that they have gained an advocate for life. As they continue to grow in learning and life, I’ll always be there to celebrate the wins, comfort in the losses, and push them towards their wildest dreams.” See how her students create classroom goals, complete life applicable projects, prepare for “knowledge checks,” and use word walls for accountability. Thank you for giving your heart to your students and making your lessons relevant, Sontreka! #TeachArkansas

March 19, 2019 at 2:05 PM ·

Today's Amazing Arkansas Educator is Ethan James, who left his career in photojournalism to join his wife as a fourth grade teacher at Jessieville Elementary School. This first-year teacher has a dimmed classroom with flexible seating and math problems about last night’s basketball games. He uses collaborative groups to reinforce the skills his students need to succeed. Look around his room and you will find students creating fractions with hands-on manipulatives and taking photos with iPads to prove their learning. Students are reading and writing about math while also competing against each other through online platforms like Prodigy. We are so glad that Mr. James changed professions so that he could impact today and inspire tomorrow as an Arkansas teacher! See more photos of his classroom in the comments. #TeachArkansas
